summary: This is a memorandum filed by Ghislaine Maxwell's defense attorneys in support of her third motion for release on bail. It proposes two new bail conditions: renunciation of her French and British citizenship, and the placement of her and her spouse's assets under the monitoring of a retired federal judge. The document argues these conditions address the court's flight risk concerns and highlights pending pretrial motions challenging the government's case.

persons.name: Ghislaine Maxwell
persons.context: The defendant seeking release on bail, charged with crimes related to Jeffrey Epstein. She is proposing to renounce her foreign citizenships and have her assets monitored.

persons.name: Bobbi C. Sternheim
persons.context: Lead attorney for Ghislaine Maxwell, filing this memorandum in support of the bail motion.

persons.name: Christian R. Everdell
persons.context: Attorney for Ghislaine Maxwell from Cohen & Gresser LLP, listed as counsel on the filing.

persons.name: Jeffrey S. Pagliuca
persons.context: Attorney for Ghislaine Maxwell from Haddon, Morgan & Foreman P.C., listed as counsel on the filing.

persons.name: Laura A. Menninger
persons.context: Attorney for Ghislaine Maxwell from Haddon, Morgan & Foreman P.C., listed as counsel on the filing.

persons.name: William S. Duffey, Jr.
persons.context: A retired federal District Court judge and former U.S. Attorney who has agreed to oversee Maxwell's assets as a condition of bail.

persons.name: Jeffrey Epstein
persons.context: Referenced as the individual Maxwell is allegedly being used as a 'substitute replacement' for in the public narrative.

persons.name: Dominique Strauss-Kahn
persons.context: Former IMF head used as a comparative example in a footnote where a French citizen with no U.S. ties was granted bail on serious charges.

connections.description: Sternheim is the lead defense attorney filing this bail motion on behalf of Maxwell.
Everdell is listed as defense counsel for Maxwell on this filing.
Pagliuca is listed as defense counsel for Maxwell on this filing.
Menninger is listed as defense counsel for Maxwell on this filing.
Duffey is proposed to be appointed as an asset monitor to oversee Maxwell's finances if bail is granted.
Maxwell is described in the document as being depicted as a 'substitute replacement' for Epstein.

events.title: Pretrial Motion Deadline
events.description: Deadline by which Ghislaine Maxwell's defense team filed twelve pretrial motions challenging the indictment.

events.title: Filing of Third Bail Motion Memorandum
events.description: Defense files this memorandum proposing new bail conditions including citizenship renunciation and asset monitoring.

locations: United States District Court Southern District of New York
London (referenced regarding sale of a house)
keyFacts: Ghislaine Maxwell's defense proposed she renounce her French and British citizenship to eliminate concerns she might seek refuge in those countries.
The defense proposed placing Maxwell's and her spouse's assets under the monitoring and co-signature authority of retired federal judge William S. Duffey, Jr.

Maxwell's attorneys filed twelve pretrial motions by January 25, 2021, challenging the indictment on grounds including breach of a non-prosecution agreement, pre-indictment delay, and statute of limitations.
The document argues Maxwell is not a flight risk or danger to the community, contrasting her case with that of Dominique Strauss-Kahn, who was granted bail.
The filing states Maxwell has lived in the United States for 30 years, is an American citizen, and has strong family ties in the country.
